awd_abstract_narration:
Because there is a high-need for well-qualified workers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields for the numerous scientific and manufacturing industries in Central New Mexico, this project at the University of New Mexico Valencia Branch (UNM-V) is designed to prepare students for future employment and thus have a significant economic impact on the region as well as the scholarship students and their families. The project will provide funding to enable about 15 academically talented, low-income students per year to attend college full time, graduate with a certificate or associate degree, and find employment in high wage jobs or transfer to four-year research universities. Building on the success of a prior S-STEM award, this project will expand the activities to improve retention, graduation, and transfer rates of students in STEM degree programs. The college will continue to build its Associate of Science in General Science, Pre-Engineering, and Mathematics degrees that prepare students for transfer to four-year institutions such as UNM Main, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, or New Mexico State University while continuing to offer certificates and associate degrees in applied science and information technology. Students attaining AAS degrees will be able to find regional employment or transfer to four year degree programs in technical management or computer science. Since UNM-V is a two-year community college, a Minority Serving Institution and a Hispanic Serving Institution, it is anticipated that the lessons learned from a comprehensive evaluation and research study will provide information regarding the improvement of retention, graduation, and transfer rates for a diverse group of low-income STEM students that can be broadly disseminated and serve as a model for similar institutions.

The project will provide mentoring and support services that will build confidence and personal motivation in students. Scholarship recipients will enroll in an Experiential Learning Seminar that is an introduction to a library research and scientific methods course for STEM majors. These students will be tracked by cohorts each semester and compared to a similar group of STEM majors who do not enroll in the course. Through intensive financial and academic student support, such as tutoring, career advisement, the seminar course, non-academic counseling, and faculty mentoring, the program plans to increase the retention and completion rates of participants as well as sustain strong cumulative grade point averages and better prepare students for transfer.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University Of New Mexico - Valencia Branch

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
BACKGROUND

                                                                                                                                                                 Over the five years of the NSF-STEM Project funded through the National Science Foundation (NSF), the University of New Mexico-Valencia campus has provided students with guidance, academic and financial support to complete the first two years of basic requirements for degrees in STEM fields such as engineering, health sciences, and math. We had a change in STEM Project managers from Brittany Padilla to Joseph Romero and the project continued without interruption. Both Program Managers recruited students and supported them throughout COVID and after the Pandemic.

 

                                                                                                                                                                 The Project was designed to focus on student support based on social connectedness theory.  It provided students with financial assistance, a STEM orientation class, a second course on library research /scientific methods, opportunity to participate in an undergraduate research project (as part of a team/cohort), weekly tutoring, faculty mentors’ meetings, supplemental instruction sessions for chemistry, and at least once /semester meetings with the STEM/Transfer Advisor and Career Services Manager. These meetings assisted students with mapping out degree pathways, fine tuning career goals, and discussed job shadowing, informational interviews, or optional STEM internship opportunities.

During years Four and Five for the NSF STEM, the Project and classes were online in order to reduce COVID-19 pandemic virus exposure. This last year more classes met face to face although UNM-Valencia has worked to make all core requirements available as online courses.

 

Some students preferred online classes to in person but most students enjoyed resuming face to face learning and teaching. Several of the current students asked during the interviews to be able to meet with their colleagues, fellow NSF scholars, as a group and to get to know one another. The students this year continued to accomplish the outcomes targeted with the objectives for the Project. Students reported receiving all the elements of the Project and indicated satisfaction overall with all components and with the support and guidance they received.

 

Overall, during the life of this NSF-STEM Project at UNM-Valencia, measurable objectives have been accomplished even though the Pandemic slowed everyone’s progress and was a barrier the students and faculty had to contend with. Retention in the Project was high and students who participated completed more credit hours with a higher average GPA than did their counterparts in STEM academics who were not part of the Project. The Project provided ongoing support and guidance to first-generation college, Hispanic students and they met the aggressive objectives outlined in the Project proposal/design. They were more than satisfied with the Project and were grateful for the support they received.   

 

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2024
Modified by: Benjamin J Flicker

BACKGROUND


 Over the five years of the NSF-STEM Project funded through the National Science Foundation (NSF), the University of New Mexico-Valencia campus has provided students with guidance, academic and financial support to complete the first two years of basic requirements for degrees in STEM fields such as engineering, health sciences, and math. We had a change in STEM Project managers from Brittany Padilla to Joseph Romero and the project continued without interruption. Both Program Managers recruited students and supported them throughout COVID and after the Pandemic.





 The Project was designed to focus on student support based on social connectedness theory. It provided students with financial assistance, a STEM orientation class, a second course on library research /scientific methods, opportunity to participate in an undergraduate research project (as part of a team/cohort), weekly tutoring, faculty mentors meetings, supplemental instruction sessions for chemistry, and at least once /semester meetings with the STEM/Transfer Advisor and Career Services Manager. These meetings assisted students with mapping out degree pathways, fine tuning career goals, and discussed job shadowing, informational interviews, or optional STEM internship opportunities.


During years Four and Five for the NSF STEM, the Project and classes were online in order to reduce COVID-19 pandemic virus exposure. This last year more classes met face to face although UNM-Valencia has worked to make all core requirements available as online courses.





Some students preferred online classes to in person but most students enjoyed resuming face to face learning and teaching. Several of the current students asked during the interviews to be able to meet with their colleagues, fellow NSF scholars, as a group and to get to know one another. The students this year continued to accomplish the outcomes targeted with the objectives for the Project. Students reported receiving all the elements of the Project and indicated satisfaction overall with all components and with the support and guidance they received.





Overall, during the life of this NSF-STEM Project at UNM-Valencia, measurable objectives have been accomplished even though the Pandemic slowed everyones progress and was a barrier the students and faculty had to contend with. Retention in the Project was high and students who participated completed more credit hours with a higher average GPA than did their counterparts in STEM academics who were not part of the Project. The Project provided ongoing support and guidance to first-generation college, Hispanic students and they met the aggressive objectives outlined in the Project proposal/design. They were more than satisfied with the Project and were grateful for the support they received.
